social_media_trends.csv:
Please answer the following statements according to your behaviour throughout the Covid-19 pandemic i.e., ‘throughout lockdown I took part in...’/ ‘throughout lockdown I was inspired by social media to take part in...’
Some of the statements have prompts and examples to aid recall, but please think carefully so that answers are as genuine as possible. This questionnaire should take no more than 5 minutes
Following a new exercise instructor/influencer (e.g. Grace fit, Joe Wicks, Chloe Ting)
Cooking new things/ cooking challenges (e.g. ‘tomato feta pasta’ on tiktok)
Baking new things/ baking challenges (e.g. ‘cloud bread’, ‘pancake cereal’, ‘rainbow cakes’)
Campaigning for social and political movements
Downloaded/ started using video chat apps more often (e.g. ‘houseparty’)
Challenges involving alcoholic beverages (e.g. Snapchat/Instagram pint challenge)
Shopping (e.g. buying new appliances, clothes, cosmetics, ingredients, or any other product)
Changing my style or physical appearances
Changing my beliefs or believing in something new (e.g. political, religious, spiritual, theoretical, conspiracy)
Changing my opinion on the covid vaccine - (e.g. whether or not to receive it)
Having a change in opinion/ acceptance of previously controversial ideas (e.g. body positivity, diminishing gender norms)
Forming alternative methods of income (e.g. crypto/stocks, small business)
Watching trending TV shows/movies (e.g. tiger king)
Changing my attitudes towards people present on online platforms i.e. Celebrities and influencers (e.g. ‘cancel culture’, James Charles, Kanye West)
Renovating/ decorating my home or another home or part of
Following a trend that includes my pet (e.g. getting my dog to hold an egg, showing your dog as a puppy compared to now)

autism_quotient.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own.
I prefer to do things the same way over and over again.
If I try to imagine something, I find it very easy to create a picture in my mind.
I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things.
I often notice small sounds when others do not.
I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information.
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations.
I tend to notice details that others do not.
I would rather go to a library than a party.
I find making up stories easy.
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things.
I tend to have very strong interests which I get upset about if I can't pursue.
When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways.
When I'm reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions.
I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction.
I find it hard to make new friends.
I notice patterns in things all the time.
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum.
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed.
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going.
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me.
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details.
I am not very good at remembering phone numbers.
I don't usually notice small changes in a situation, or a person's appearance.
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored.
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once.
When I talk on the phone, I'm not sure when it's my turn to speak.
I am often the last to understand the point of a joke.
I find it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face.
If there is an interruption, I can switch back to what I was doing very quickly.
I am good at social chit-chat.
People often tell me that I keep going on and on about the same thing.
When I was young, I used to enjoy playing games involving pretending with other children.
I like to collect information about categories of things (e.g. types of car, types of bird, types of train, types of plant, etc.).
I find it difficult to imagine what it would be like to be someone else.
I like to plan any activities I participate in carefully.
I find it difficult to work out people's intentions.
I am not very good at remembering people's date of birth.
I find it very easy to play games with children that involve pretending.

csi.csv: During the COVID-19 pandemic, indicate to what extent you...
Let your feelings out to a friend?
Rearranged things around you so that your problem had the best chance of being resolved?
Brainstormed all possible solutions before deciding what do to?
Tried to distract yourself from the problem?
Accepted sympathy and understanding from someone?
Did all you could to keep others from seeing how bad things really were?
Talked to people about the situation because talking about it helped you to feel better?
Set some goals for yourself to deal with the situation?
Tried different ways to solve the problem until you found one that worked?
Confided your fears and worries to a friend or relative?
Spent more time than usual alone?
Told people about the situation because just talking about it helped you to come up with solutions?
Thought about what needed to be done to straighten things out?
Turned your full attention to solving the problem?
Formed a plan of action in your mind?
Went to someone (friend or professional) in order to help you feel better?
Stood firm and fought for what you wanted in the situation?
Avoided being with people in general?
Buried yourself in a hobby or sports activity to avoid the problem?
Went to a friend to help you feel better about the problem?
Went to a friend for advice on how to change the situation?
Accepted sympathy and understanding from friends who had the same problem?
Fantasized about how things could have been different?
Identified with characters in novels or movies?
Wished that people would just leave you alone?
Accepted help from a friend or relative?
Sought reassurance from those who know you best?
Tried to carefully plan a course of action rather than acting on impulse?

I prefer to be direct and forthright when I talk with people.

It is important for me that I do my job better than the others.
I enjoy working in situations involving competitions with others.
When another person does better than I do, I get tense and aroused.
Without competition it is impossible to have a good society.
Some people emphasise winning; I am not one of them.
My happiness depends very much on the happiness of those around me.
I like sharing little things with my neighbours.
The wellbeing of my co-workers is important to me.

If a co-worker gets a prize, I would feel proud.

I would do what would please my family.

We should keep our ageing parents with us at home.
Children should feel honoured if their parents receive a distinguished award.
Children should be taught to place duty before pleasure.
I would sacrifice an activity I enjoy if my family did not approve.
I hate to disagree with others in my group.
Before making a major trip, I consult with most members of my family and many friends.

In each trial, you will be presented with a video of an actor, expressing a certain emotion. After each trial, please select which emotion that was displayed on the actor’s face. Please try and respond as quickly and accurately as possible.

You will then be asked to rate how confident you were that the emotion label you selected represented the emotion shown by the face. This will be from 1 (not at all confident) to 10 (completely confident).

Before you begin, ensure that you are in a quiet place and use headphones. You will be able to test your sound before starting the trials.

Reading RG6 6AL

Katie Fletcherk.m.fletcher@student.reading.ac.uk
Sophia Hameed yh002430@student.reading.ac.uk
Phoebe Watsontt001681@student.reading.ac.uk
Michael Faulknermichael.faulkner@student.reading.ac.uk
Chloe FarrKt019611@student.reading.ac.uk
Richard Barrettyr011996@student.reading.ac.uk
Finlay BelcherEq019255@student.reading.ac.uk

Title of Study: Investigating autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study investigating autism, your experience of the pandemic, how much you engage with different types of screen time, and how much you experience anxiety or depressive symptoms.

In the experiment you will be presented with a series of questionnaires and a task that requires you identify emotions. Some specific questions will ask about your religion and drinking behaviour in response to the pandemic. The experiment should take no longer than 2 hours in total. You may not wish to participate in this study if answering questions relating to the topics in the title could cause you distress. Please note that these questionnaires are not being used for diagnosis. If you want to check if you have problems with any of the above issues you may want to check in with a health professional. We would like to highlight some sources of support that relate to the above topics that you can check in with:
Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

We foresee few risks during the experiment, but the questionnaires will reflect on topics in the title, politics, religion and alcohol which may evoke an emotional response. Thus, the study may include a risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions. If you are concerned about these topics then you may discontinue your participation at any time.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you are a Psychology student then you will receive 2 credits through SONA.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.

Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.
I understand that my participation in this study is voluntary and that I may withdraw any time without giving any reason.
I have read the information sheet about this study and the procedure of the study has been explained to me.
I have been given the opportunity to ask any questions that I may have about the study and these have been answered to my satisfaction.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.
bsc-2021-debrief.csv:
THANK YOU!

Thank you for participating in the study. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationships between autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression.

We hope that you have found the study an interesting and positive experience. However, if you have found any part of this experience to be distressing and you wish to speak to one of the experimenters, please contact Dr Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk).

There are also a few organisations listed below that you can contact.

Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your GP can also help you find specific support services in your local area. If you are in immediate risk, or you feel like you cannot keep yourself safe, please phone 999.

Thank you again for taking part in our research. If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.


Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.
autism_quotient.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own.
I prefer to do things the same way over and over again.
If I try to imagine something, I find it very easy to create a picture in my mind.
I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things.
I often notice small sounds when others do not.
I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information.
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations.
I tend to notice details that others do not.
I would rather go to a library than a party.
I find making up stories easy.
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things.
I tend to have very strong interests which I get upset about if I can't pursue.
When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways.
When I'm reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions.
I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction.
I find it hard to make new friends.
I notice patterns in things all the time.
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum.
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed.
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going.
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me.
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details.
I am not very good at remembering phone numbers.
I don't usually notice small changes in a situation, or a person's appearance.
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored.
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once.
When I talk on the phone, I'm not sure when it's my turn to speak.
I am often the last to understand the point of a joke.
I find it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face.
If there is an interruption, I can switch back to what I was doing very quickly.
I am good at social chit-chat.
People often tell me that I keep going on and on about the same thing.
When I was young, I used to enjoy playing games involving pretending with other children.
I like to collect information about categories of things (e.g. types of car, types of bird, types of train, types of plant, etc.).
I find it difficult to imagine what it would be like to be someone else.
I like to plan any activities I participate in carefully.
I find it difficult to work out people's intentions.
I am not very good at remembering people's date of birth.
I find it very easy to play games with children that involve pretending.

digital_activity.csv: In this survey we would like to know how much time you spend on a variety of screen based activities on your phones. Please follow these instructions for Android and Apple phones to help to try to accurately gauge these numbers. If these instructions do not work for your phone then please try to make the best estimate you can with the information you have available to you.

Android:

- Go to your settings app
- Select the "Digital wellbeing and parental controls" tab
- Click on the "Dashboard" option
- This will show you the figures for each app individually
- For each category, please work out the total hours spent by adding together the hours for each relevant app

Apple:

- Go to your settings app
- Select the "Screen Time" tab
Click on "See all activity"
(or you might need to select the summary of the different activities to open the more comprehensive list)
if you are seeing the summary for today, you might need to change this to "Last 7 Days"
Then select categories under the "Most used" tab
For each category, it will show you the amount of time in hours you have spent doing those activities in the week

For the below questions you'll be asked to say how many hours and minutes you spend on each activity for the last 7 days. For example, if you spent 90 minutes during the week on games, you would write 1 in the "hour" input, and 30 in the "minutes" input
Social (Instagram, Snapchat, Facebook, Text Messages and Whatsapp; hours)
Social (Instagram, Snapchat, Facebook, Text Messages and Whatsapp; minutes)
Video/Streaming Entertainment (Youtube, Netflix and other  Streaming sites; hours)
Video/Streaming Entertainment (Youtube, Netflix and other  Streaming sites; minutes)
Shopping and Food (food delivery apps and shopping apps; hours)
Shopping and Food (food delivery apps and shopping apps; minutes)

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional|Marked or notabale

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional|Marked or notabale

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional|Marked or notabale

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional (does not affect others)|Marked or notable (occasionally affects others)
Do you get upset about minor changes to objects (e.g. flecks of dirt on your clothes, minor scratches on objects?)
Never or rarely|Mild or occasional (does not affect others)|Marked or notable (occasionally affects others)

Title of Study: Investigating autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study investigating autism, your experience of the pandemic, how much you engage with different types of screen time, and how much you experience anxiety or depressive symptoms.

In the experiment you will be presented with a series of questionnaires and a task that requires you identify emotions. Some specific questions will ask about your religion and drinking behaviour in response to the pandemic. The experiment should take no longer than 2 hours in total. You may not wish to participate in this study if answering questions relating to the topics in the title could cause you distress. Please note that these questionnaires are not being used for diagnosis. If you want to check if you have problems with any of the above issues you may want to check in with a health professional. We would like to highlight some sources of support that relate to the above topics that you can check in with:
Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

We foresee few risks during the experiment, but the questionnaires will reflect on topics in the title, politics, religion and alcohol which may evoke an emotional response. Thus, the study may include a risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions. If you are concerned about these topics then you may discontinue your participation at any time.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you are a Psychology student then you will receive 2 credits through SONA.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.

Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.
I understand that my participation in this study is voluntary and that I may withdraw any time without giving any reason.
I have read the information sheet about this study and the procedure of the study has been explained to me.
I have been given the opportunity to ask any questions that I may have about the study and these have been answered to my satisfaction.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.

bsc-2021-debrief.csv:
THANK YOU!

Thank you for participating in the study. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationships between autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression.

We hope that you have found the study an interesting and positive experience. However, if you have found any part of this experience to be distressing and you wish to speak to one of the experimenters, please contact Dr Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk).

There are also a few organisations listed below that you can contact.

Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your GP can also help you find specific support services in your local area. If you are in immediate risk, or you feel like you cannot keep yourself safe, please phone 999.

Thank you again for taking part in our research. If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.


Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.

Finlay BelcherEq019255@student.reading.ac.uk

Title of Study: Investigating autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study investigating autism, your experience of the pandemic, how much you engage with different types of screen time, and how much you experience anxiety or depressive symptoms.

In the experiment you will be presented with a series of questionnaires and a task that requires you identify emotions. Some specific questions will ask about your religion and drinking behaviour in response to the pandemic. The experiment should take no longer than 2 hours in total. You may not wish to participate in this study if answering questions relating to the topics in the title could cause you distress. Please note that these questionnaires are not being used for diagnosis. If you want to check if you have problems with any of the above issues you may want to check in with a health professional. We would like to highlight some sources of support that relate to the above topics that you can check in with:
Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

We foresee few risks during the experiment, but the questionnaires will reflect on topics in the title, politics, religion and alcohol which may evoke an emotional response. Thus, the study may include a risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions. If you are concerned about these topics then you may discontinue your participation at any time.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you are a Psychology student then you will receive 2 credits through SONA.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.

Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.
I understand that my participation in this study is voluntary and that I may withdraw any time without giving any reason.
I have read the information sheet about this study and the procedure of the study has been explained to me.
I have been given the opportunity to ask any questions that I may have about the study and these have been answered to my satisfaction.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.

bsc-2021-debrief.csv:
THANK YOU!

Thank you for participating in the study. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationships between autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression.

We hope that you have found the study an interesting and positive experience. However, if you have found any part of this experience to be distressing and you wish to speak to one of the experimenters, please contact Dr Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk).

There are also a few organisations listed below that you can contact.

Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your GP can also help you find specific support services in your local area. If you are in immediate risk, or you feel like you cannot keep yourself safe, please phone 999.

Thank you again for taking part in our research. If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.


Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.

item,phasetype,max_time,text,shuffle_1,survey,alphabetical_list,audio_check_file,possible_responses, 0,instruct,user,"

This study will take about 2 hours. Please make sure that you are in a quiet place when you start.

Please do not close the window before you receive a message stating ""The study is now complete - thank you for participating!""

Data is saved after each survey/trial, so if the window closes before the end please contact the lead researcher Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk) to ask about how to proceed.

",off,,,,, 0,survey,user,This is the start of a new experiment.,off,bsc-2021-info.csv,,,, 0,instruct,user,"

In each trial, you will be presented with a video of an actor, expressing a certain emotion. After each trial, please select which emotion that was displayed on the actor’s face. Please try and respond as quickly and accurately as possible.

You will then be asked to rate how confident you were that the emotion label you selected represented the emotion shown by the face. This will be from 1 (not at all confident) to 10 (completely confident).

Before you begin, ensure that you are in a quiet place and use headphones. You will be able to test your sound before starting the trials.

",off,,,,, 0,audio_check_code,user,"Participants should have a multiple choice when presented with an audio file of which phrase they've just heard. University of Reading


School of Psychology and Clinical Language Sciences
Whiteknights
Reading RG6 6AL

Investigator(s): Email:
Dr. Anthony Haffey a.haffey@reading.ac.uk
Researcher(s):
Senali Kohomange Kr019003@student.reading.ac.uk

Eve Hammondlo002699@student.reading.ac.uk

Uche Ihearahupn014658@stduent.reading.ac.uk
Jasmine StringerYi003613@student.reading.ac.uk
Katie Fletcherk.m.fletcher@student.reading.ac.uk
Sophia Hameed yh002430@student.reading.ac.uk
Phoebe Watsontt001681@student.reading.ac.uk
Michael Faulknermichael.faulkner@student.reading.ac.uk
Chloe FarrKt019611@student.reading.ac.uk
Richard Barrettyr011996@student.reading.ac.uk
Finlay BelcherEq019255@student.reading.ac.uk

Title of Study: Investigating autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study investigating autism, your experience of the pandemic, how much you engage with different types of screen time, and how much you experience anxiety or depressive symptoms.

In the experiment you will be presented with a series of questionnaires and a task that requires you identify emotions. Some specific questions will ask about your religion and drinking behaviour in response to the pandemic. The experiment should take no longer than 2 hours in total. You may not wish to participate in this study if answering questions relating to the topics in the title could cause you distress. Please note that these questionnaires are not being used for diagnosis. If you want to check if you have problems with any of the above issues you may want to check in with a health professional. We would like to highlight some sources of support that relate to the above topics that you can check in with:
Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

We foresee few risks during the experiment, but the questionnaires will reflect on topics in the title, politics, religion and alcohol which may evoke an emotional response. Thus, the study may include a risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions. If you are concerned about these topics then you may discontinue your participation at any time.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you are a Psychology student then you will receive 2 credits through SONA.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.

Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.
I understand that my participation in this study is voluntary and that I may withdraw any time without giving any reason.
I have read the information sheet about this study and the procedure of the study has been explained to me.
I have been given the opportunity to ask any questions that I may have about the study and these have been answered to my satisfaction.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.
bsc-2021-debrief.csv:
THANK YOU!

Thank you for participating in the study. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationships between autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression.

We hope that you have found the study an interesting and positive experience. However, if you have found any part of this experience to be distressing and you wish to speak to one of the experimenters, please contact Dr Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk).

There are also a few organisations listed below that you can contact.

Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your GP can also help you find specific support services in your local area. If you are in immediate risk, or you feel like you cannot keep yourself safe, please phone 999.

Thank you again for taking part in our research. If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.


Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.
adhd.csv: Below are a series of statements. Please answer them as accurately as possible.
How often do you have trouble wrapping up the final details of a project, once the challenging parts have been done?
How often do you have difficulty getting things in order when you have to do a task that requires organization?
How often do you have problems remembering appointments or obligations?
When you have a task that requires a lot of thought, how often do you avoid or delay getting started?
How often do you fidget or squirm with your hands or feet when you have to sit down for a long time?
How often do you feel overly active and compelled to do things, like you were driven by a motor?

autism_quotient.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own.
I prefer to do things the same way over and over again.
If I try to imagine something, I find it very easy to create a picture in my mind.
I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things.
I often notice small sounds when others do not.
I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information.
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations.
I tend to notice details that others do not.
I would rather go to a library than a party.
I find making up stories easy.
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things.
I tend to have very strong interests which I get upset about if I can't pursue.
When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways.
When I'm reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions.
I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction.
I find it hard to make new friends.
I notice patterns in things all the time.
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum.
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed.
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going.
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me.
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details.
I am not very good at remembering phone numbers.
I don't usually notice small changes in a situation, or a person's appearance.
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored.
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once.
When I talk on the phone, I'm not sure when it's my turn to speak.

digital_activity.csv: In this survey we would like to know how much time you spend on a variety of screen based activities on your phones. Please follow these instructions for Android and Apple phones to help to try to accurately gauge these numbers. If these instructions do not work for your phone then please try to make the best estimate you can with the information you have available to you.

Android:

- Go to your settings app
- Select the "Digital wellbeing and parental controls" tab
- Click on the "Dashboard" option
- This will show you the figures for each app individually
- For each category, please work out the total hours spent by adding together the hours for each relevant app

Apple:

- Go to your settings app
- Select the "Screen Time" tab
Click on "See all activity"
(or you might need to select the summary of the different activities to open the more comprehensive list)
if you are seeing the summary for today, you might need to change this to "Last 7 Days"
Then select categories under the "Most used" tab
For each category, it will show you the amount of time in hours you have spent doing those activities in the week

For the below questions you'll be asked to say how many hours and minutes you spend on each activity for the last 7 days. For example, if you spent 90 minutes during the week on games, you would write 1 in the "hour" input, and 30 in the "minutes" input
Social (Instagram, Snapchat, Facebook, Text Messages and Whatsapp; hours)

Title of Study: Investigating autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study investigating autism, your experience of the pandemic, how much you engage with different types of screen time, and how much you experience anxiety or depressive symptoms.

In the experiment you will be presented with a series of questionnaires and a task that requires you identify emotions. Some specific questions will ask about your religion and drinking behaviour in response to the pandemic. The experiment should take no longer than 2 hours in total. You may not wish to participate in this study if answering questions relating to the topics in the title could cause you distress. Please note that these questionnaires are not being used for diagnosis. If you want to check if you have problems with any of the above issues you may want to check in with a health professional. We would like to highlight some sources of support that relate to the above topics that you can check in with:
Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

We foresee few risks during the experiment, but the questionnaires will reflect on topics in the title, politics, religion and alcohol which may evoke an emotional response. Thus, the study may include a risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions. If you are concerned about these topics then you may discontinue your participation at any time.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you are a Psychology student then you will receive 2 credits through SONA.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.

Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.
I understand that my participation in this study is voluntary and that I may withdraw any time without giving any reason.
I have read the information sheet about this study and the procedure of the study has been explained to me.
I have been given the opportunity to ask any questions that I may have about the study and these have been answered to my satisfaction.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.
autism_quotient.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own.

I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things.

I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information.
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations.
I tend to notice details that others do not.
I would rather go to a library than a party.
I find making up stories easy.
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things.

When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways.

I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction.
I find it hard to make new friends.
I notice patterns in things all the time.
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum.
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed.
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going.
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me.
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details.
I am not very good at remembering phone numbers.
I don't usually notice small changes in a situation, or a person's appearance.
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored.
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once.
When I talk on the phone, I'm not sure when it's my turn to speak.
I am often the last to understand the point of a joke.
I find it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face.
If there is an interruption, I can switch back to what I was doing very quickly.
I am good at social chit-chat.
People often tell me that I keep going on and on about the same thing.
When I was young, I used to enjoy playing games involving pretending with other children.
I like to collect information about categories of things (e.g. types of car, types of bird, types of train, types of plant, etc.).
I find it difficult to imagine what it would be like to be someone else.
I like to plan any activities I participate in carefully.
I find it difficult to work out people's intentions.
I am not very good at remembering people's date of birth.
I find it very easy to play games with children that involve pretending.
bsc-2021-debrief.csv:
THANK YOU!

Thank you for participating in the study. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationships between autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression.

We hope that you have found the study an interesting and positive experience. However, if you have found any part of this experience to be distressing and you wish to speak to one of the experimenters, please contact Dr Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk).

There are also a few organisations listed below that you can contact.

Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your GP can also help you find specific support services in your local area. If you are in immediate risk, or you feel like you cannot keep yourself safe, please phone 999.

Thank you again for taking part in our research. If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.


Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

We foresee few risks during the experiment, but the questionnaires will reflect on topics in the title, politics, religion and alcohol which may evoke an emotional response. Thus, the study may include a risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions. If you are concerned about these topics then you may discontinue your participation at any time.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you are a Psychology student then you will receive 2 credits through SONA.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.

Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

bsc-2021-debrief.csv:
THANK YOU!

Thank you for participating in the study. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationships between autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression.

We hope that you have found the study an interesting and positive experience. However, if you have found any part of this experience to be distressing and you wish to speak to one of the experimenters, please contact Dr Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk).

There are also a few organisations listed below that you can contact.

Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your GP can also help you find specific support services in your local area. If you are in immediate risk, or you feel like you cannot keep yourself safe, please phone 999.

Thank you again for taking part in our research. If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.


Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.

autism_quotient.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own.
I prefer to do things the same way over and over again.
If I try to imagine something, I find it very easy to create a picture in my mind.
I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things.
I often notice small sounds when others do not.
I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information.
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations.
I tend to notice details that others do not.
I would rather go to a library than a party.
I find making up stories easy.
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things.
I tend to have very strong interests which I get upset about if I can't pursue.
When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways.
When I'm reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions.
I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction.
I find it hard to make new friends.
I notice patterns in things all the time.
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum.
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed.
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going.
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me.
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details.
I am not very good at remembering phone numbers.
I don't usually notice small changes in a situation, or a person's appearance.
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored.
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once.

Title of Study: Investigating autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study investigating autism, your experience of the pandemic, how much you engage with different types of screen time, and how much you experience anxiety or depressive symptoms.

In the experiment you will be presented with a series of questionnaires and a task that requires you identify emotions. Some specific questions will ask about your religion and drinking behaviour in response to the pandemic. The experiment should take no longer than 2 hours in total. You may not wish to participate in this study if answering questions relating to the topics in the title could cause you distress. Please note that these questionnaires are not being used for diagnosis. If you want to check if you have problems with any of the above issues you may want to check in with a health professional. We would like to highlight some sources of support that relate to the above topics that you can check in with:
Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

We foresee few risks during the experiment, but the questionnaires will reflect on topics in the title, politics, religion and alcohol which may evoke an emotional response. Thus, the study may include a risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions. If you are concerned about these topics then you may discontinue your participation at any time.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you are a Psychology student then you will receive 2 credits through SONA.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.

Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.
I understand that my participation in this study is voluntary and that I may withdraw any time without giving any reason.
I have read the information sheet about this study and the procedure of the study has been explained to me.
I have been given the opportunity to ask any questions that I may have about the study and these have been answered to my satisfaction.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.

autism_quotient.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own.
I prefer to do things the same way over and over again.
If I try to imagine something, I find it very easy to create a picture in my mind.
I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things.
I often notice small sounds when others do not.
I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information.
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations.
I tend to notice details that others do not.
I would rather go to a library than a party.
I find making up stories easy.
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things.
I tend to have very strong interests which I get upset about if I can't pursue.
When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways.
When I'm reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions.
I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction.
I find it hard to make new friends.
I notice patterns in things all the time.
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum.
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed.
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going.
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me.
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details.

Finlay BelcherEq019255@student.reading.ac.uk

Title of Study: Investigating autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study investigating autism, your experience of the pandemic, how much you engage with different types of screen time, and how much you experience anxiety or depressive symptoms.

In the experiment you will be presented with a series of questionnaires and a task that requires you identify emotions. Some specific questions will ask about your religion and drinking behaviour in response to the pandemic. The experiment should take no longer than 2 hours in total. You may not wish to participate in this study if answering questions relating to the topics in the title could cause you distress. Please note that these questionnaires are not being used for diagnosis. If you want to check if you have problems with any of the above issues you may want to check in with a health professional. We would like to highlight some sources of support that relate to the above topics that you can check in with:
Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

We foresee few risks during the experiment, but the questionnaires will reflect on topics in the title, politics, religion and alcohol which may evoke an emotional response. Thus, the study may include a risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions. If you are concerned about these topics then you may discontinue your participation at any time.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you are a Psychology student then you will receive 2 credits through SONA.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.

Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.
I understand that my participation in this study is voluntary and that I may withdraw any time without giving any reason.
I have read the information sheet about this study and the procedure of the study has been explained to me.
I have been given the opportunity to ask any questions that I may have about the study and these have been answered to my satisfaction.
I understand that the data collected from me in this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that they can be consulted and re-used by others.

digital_activity.csv: In this survey we would like to know how much time you spend on a variety of screen based activities on your phones. Please follow these instructions for Android and Apple phones to help to try to accurately gauge these numbers. If these instructions do not work for your phone then please try to make the best estimate you can with the information you have available to you.

Android:

- Go to your settings app
- Select the "Digital wellbeing and parental controls" tab
- Click on the "Dashboard" option
- This will show you the figures for each app individually
- For each category, please work out the total hours spent by adding together the hours for each relevant app

Apple:

- Go to your settings app
- Select the "Screen Time" tab
Click on "See all activity"
(or you might need to select the summary of the different activities to open the more comprehensive list)
if you are seeing the summary for today, you might need to change this to "Last 7 Days"
Then select categories under the "Most used" tab
For each category, it will show you the amount of time in hours you have spent doing those activities in the week

For the below questions you'll be asked to say how many hours and minutes you spend on each activity for the last 7 days. For example, if you spent 90 minutes during the week on games, you would write 1 in the "hour" input, and 30 in the "minutes" input
Social (Instagram, Snapchat, Facebook, Text Messages and Whatsapp; hours)
Social (Instagram, Snapchat, Facebook, Text Messages and Whatsapp; minutes)
Video/Streaming Entertainment (Youtube, Netflix and other  Streaming sites; hours)
Video/Streaming Entertainment (Youtube, Netflix and other  Streaming sites; minutes)

Shopping and Food (food delivery apps and shopping apps; minutes)

Never or rarely|One or more time daily|15 or more times daily

Never or rarely|One or more time daily|15 or more times daily

Never or rarely|One or more time daily|15 or more times daily

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional|Marked or notabale

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional|Marked or notabale

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional|Marked or notabale

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional (does not affect others)|Marked or notable (occasionally affects others)

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional (does not affect others)|Marked or notable (occasionally affects others)

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional (does not affect others)|Marked or notable (occasionally affects others)

Never or rarely|Mild or occasional (does not affect others)|Marked or notable (occasionally affects others)

digital_activity.csv: In this survey we would like to know how much time you spend on a variety of screen based activities on your phones. Please follow these instructions for Android and Apple phones to help to try to accurately gauge these numbers. If these instructions do not work for your phone then please try to make the best estimate you can with the information you have available to you.

Android:

- Go to your settings app
- Select the "Digital wellbeing and parental controls" tab
- Click on the "Dashboard" option
- This will show you the figures for each app individually
- For each category, please work out the total hours spent by adding together the hours for each relevant app

Apple:

- Go to your settings app
- Select the "Screen Time" tab
Click on "See all activity"
(or you might need to select the summary of the different activities to open the more comprehensive list)
if you are seeing the summary for today, you might need to change this to "Last 7 Days"
Then select categories under the "Most used" tab
For each category, it will show you the amount of time in hours you have spent doing those activities in the week

For the below questions you'll be asked to say how many hours and minutes you spend on each activity for the last 7 days. For example, if you spent 90 minutes during the week on games, you would write 1 in the "hour" input, and 30 in the "minutes" input
Social (Instagram, Snapchat, Facebook, Text Messages and Whatsapp; hours)
Social (Instagram, Snapchat, Facebook, Text Messages and Whatsapp; minutes)
Video/Streaming Entertainment (Youtube, Netflix and other  Streaming sites; hours)
Video/Streaming Entertainment (Youtube, Netflix and other  Streaming sites; minutes)
Shopping and Food (food delivery apps and shopping apps; hours)
Shopping and Food (food delivery apps and shopping apps; minutes)

Title of Study: Investigating autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression

PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

We would be grateful if you could assist us by participating in our online study investigating autism, your experience of the pandemic, how much you engage with different types of screen time, and how much you experience anxiety or depressive symptoms.

In the experiment you will be presented with a series of questionnaires and a task that requires you identify emotions. Some specific questions will ask about your religion and drinking behaviour in response to the pandemic. The experiment should take no longer than 2 hours in total. You may not wish to participate in this study if answering questions relating to the topics in the title could cause you distress. Please note that these questionnaires are not being used for diagnosis. If you want to check if you have problems with any of the above issues you may want to check in with a health professional. We would like to highlight some sources of support that relate to the above topics that you can check in with:
Organisation What they offer Contact Details
Mind Promotes the views and needs of people with mental health difficulties Ph: 0300 123 3393
(Monday-Friday, 9am to 6pm)
Web: www.mind.org.uk
Samaritans Confidential support for people experiencing feelings of distress or despair Ph: 116 123
(Free 24-hour helpline)
Web: www.samaritans.org.uk
SANE Emotional support, information and guidance for people affected by mental illness, their families and carers Ph: 0300 304 7000
(Daily, 4.30pm to 10.30pm)
Textcare: comfort and care via text message, sent when the person needs it most: www.sane.org.uk/textcare
Peer support forum:
www.sane.org.uk/supportforum;
Web: www.sane.org.uk/support
National Autistic Society Provides advice, guidance, help and support on the challenges autistic people and their families face. Web: www.autism.org.uk

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Data collected from this study will be preserved and made available in anonymised form, so that data can be re-used by others.

We foresee few risks during the experiment, but the questionnaires will reflect on topics in the title, politics, religion and alcohol which may evoke an emotional response. Thus, the study may include a risk of anxiety, sadness or other emotional reactions. If you are concerned about these topics then you may discontinue your participation at any time.

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

If you are a Psychology student then you will receive 2 credits through SONA.

This application has been reviewed by the University Research Ethics Committee and has been given a favourable ethical opinion for conduct ([SREC OR UREC NUMBER]).

If you have any questions or concerns about the research, please feel free to contact Anthony Haffey.

Email: a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

Thank you for your help.

THANK YOU!

Thank you for participating in the study. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationships between autistic traits, experience of the pandemic, digital behaviour, anxiety and depression.

We hope that you have found the study an interesting and positive experience. However, if you have found any part of this experience to be distressing and you wish to speak to one of the experimenters, please contact Dr Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk).

There are also a few organisations listed below that you can contact.

Your GP can also help you find specific support services in your local area. If you are in immediate risk, or you feel like you cannot keep yourself safe, please phone 999.

info_sheet.csv:
PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

Title of Project: [[Your project title]].

Name of Lead Investigator: [[Investigator]] ([[Institute]])

Invitation paragraph

You have been invited to take part in a research study. Before you decide whether to take part it is important for you to understand why the research is being done and what it will involve. Please take time to read the following information carefully and discuss it with friends and relatives if you wish to. Ask us if there is anything that is not clear or if you would like more information. Take time to decide whether you wish to take part or not. Thank you for reading this.

What is the study about?

[[describe your experiment here]].

What does the study involve?

[[what the participant will do]]

Why have I been chosen?

[[criterion, e.g. age, etc.]]

Do I have to take part?

It is up to you to decide whether or not to take part. If you do decide to take part you will be given this information sheet to keep and be asked to sign a consent form. If you decide to take part you are still free to withdraw at any time during the data collection without giving a reason.

I am interested in taking part, what do I do next?

Please find a quiet room with minimal distractions. Please ensure you have a good internet connection on a PC / laptop / tablet device. [[optional: Please do not run the study on a mobile phone]]. Make sure that you have about [[time needed]] minutes time to complete the study. Once ready please follow the link to the online study.

What if I agree to take part and then change my mind?

That is fine. If you decide to withdraw you would need to provide your participation ID to the researchers. The researcher will then delete all the data generated by that ID from their computers.

What are the possible disadvantages and risks of taking part?

[[describe risks etc. here]]

What are the possible benefits of taking part?

[[benefits here]]

Who can I complain to?

If you have a complaint regarding anything to do with this study, you can initially approach the lead investigator [[lead investigator]] ([[lead_investigator_email]]). If this achieves no satisfactory outcome, you should then contact [[person to contact next]]

Will my taking part in this study be kept confidential?

All information which is collected about you during the course of the research will be kept on a password protected database and is strictly confidential. You will be given an ID code which will be used instead of your name. Your data will be shared with the following collaborators:
[[list of collaborators]]

[[optional: Your anonymised data can be shared with other research teams interested in understating it further.]]
The raw data will be stored for up to 10 years after a study has been completed.
Members of the faculty human research ethics committee may require access to check that the study has been conducted in accordance with the approval.

What will happen to the results of the research study?

The results based on performance of the group of participants will be then analysed and submitted for publication in peer reviewed scientific journals.

Who is organising and funding the research?



[[information about researchers and funders here]]

Who has reviewed the study?

This study has been reviewed and approved by [[your ethics committee]].


How is data secured?

Data is encrypted in Collector on the participant's computer. This data cannot be decrypted without the researcher's password. For more information, go to: https://some-open-solutions.github.io/collector/encryption.html

Contact for Further Information

[[your contact information]]
I understand these instructions and am happy to continue
